## e2tree <img src="https://img.shields.io/badge/CRAN-v0.2.0-blue" alt="CRAN version" style="vertical-align: middle; margin-left: 8px;"/>

**Explainable Ensemble Trees**

<a href="https://cran.r-project.org/package=e2tree" target="_blank"><img src="https://cranlogs.r-pkg.org/badges/grand-total/e2tree" alt="CRAN Downloads"/></a>
<a href="https://github.com/massimoaria/e2tree" target="_blank"><img src="https://img.shields.io/github/stars/massimoaria/e2tree?style=social" alt="GitHub Stars"/></a>

The `e2tree` package implements the **Explainable Ensemble Trees (E2Tree)** methodology proposed by Aria et al. (2024). It provides a novel approach to explain and interpret decision tree ensemble models — such as Random Forests and XGBoost — using a single, interpretable tree-like structure.

The core idea is to generate a surrogate tree that captures the relational structure between the response variable and predictors learned by the ensemble, making complex black-box models transparent and easy to understand.

**Key features:**

- Explain **Random Forest** (via `randomForest` or `ranger`) and **XGBoost** models
- Generate interpretable **dendrogram-like visualizations**
- Compute **variable importance** measures with associated plots
- Convert E2Tree outputs to `rpart` objects for further analysis
- Support for both **classification** and **regression** tasks

**Installation:**

```r
# Stable version from CRAN
install.packages("e2tree")

# Development version from GitHub
devtools::install_github("massimoaria/e2tree")
```

**Quick example:**

```r
library(e2tree)
library(randomForest)

# Train a Random Forest
rf <- randomForest(Species ~ ., data = iris)

# Build the Explainable Ensemble Tree
result <- e2tree(rf, data = iris)

# Plot the interpretable tree
plot(result)
```

**References:**

- Aria, M., **Gnasso, A.**, Iorio, C., & Pandolfo, G. (2024). "Explainable ensemble trees". *Computational Statistics*, 39(1), 3-19. [DOI](https://doi.org/10.1007/s00180-022-01312-6)
- Aria, M., **Gnasso, A.**, Iorio, C., & Fokkema, M. (2025). "Extending Explainable Ensemble Trees to Regression Contexts". *Applied Stochastic Models in Business and Industry*, 42(1), e70064. [DOI](https://doi.org/10.1002/asmb.70064)

## bibliometrix <img src="https://img.shields.io/badge/CRAN-v5.2.1-blue" alt="CRAN version" style="vertical-align: middle; margin-left: 8px;"/>

**Comprehensive Science Mapping Analysis**

<a href="https://cran.r-project.org/package=bibliometrix" target="_blank"><img src="https://cranlogs.r-pkg.org/badges/grand-total/bibliometrix" alt="CRAN Downloads"/></a>
<a href="https://github.com/massimoaria/bibliometrix" target="_blank"><img src="https://img.shields.io/github/stars/massimoaria/bibliometrix?style=social" alt="GitHub Stars"/></a>

`bibliometrix` is an R package for quantitative research in scientometrics and bibliometrics. It provides a comprehensive workflow for science mapping analysis, supporting data import from major bibliographic databases including Scopus, Web of Science, Dimensions, OpenAlex, PubMed, Cochrane Library, and Lens.

As a **core developer team member**, I contribute to the development, maintenance, and evolution of the package and its web interface **Biblioshiny**.

**Key features:**

- Import and convert data from **7+ bibliographic databases**
- Perform **descriptive bibliometric analysis** (author productivity, citation analysis, h-index)
- Build **network matrices** for co-citation, coupling, collaboration, and co-word analysis
- Generate **thematic maps**, **thematic evolution** plots, and **conceptual structure** visualizations
- Interactive web interface via **Biblioshiny** for non-coders

**Reference:**

- Aria, M. & Cuccurullo, C. (2017). "bibliometrix: An R-tool for comprehensive science mapping analysis". *Journal of Informetrics*, 11(4), 959-975.
